case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 2370 of 1969 and Civil Appeal No. 583 of 1971

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2370 of 1969 is an appeal from the judgement and order dated 22nd May 1969 of Allahabad High Court in Spl. Appeal No. 343 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 2370 of 1969 Appeal from the judgement and order dated the 22nd May, 1969 of the Allahabad High Court in Spl. Appeal No. 343 of 1968.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 583 of 1971 is an appeal from the judgement and order dated 28th October 1970 of Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 82 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No 583 of 1971 Appeal from the Judgement order dated the 28th October, 1970 .of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 82 of 1970.

facts.text: Appellants filed a petition under Article 226 before Allahabad High Court to quash State Government order dated October 20, 1967 allowing revision by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a petition under Article 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Allahabad praying that the order passed by the State Government on October 20, 1967, allowing a revision filed by the respondent be quashed and possession of the premises in question be given to them under s. 7-A of the U. P.

facts.text: Original owner Ram Swaroop Gupta leased premises to Ms Pioneer Exhibitors and Distributors Limited, used for cinema, lease terminated June 30, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The original owner of the premises was one Ram Swaroop Gupta. He leased the premises to M s Pioneer Exhibitors and Distributors Limited. They used the premises for exhibiting cinema. That lease terminated by efflux of time on June 30, 1952.

facts.text: Gupta leased premises to Ram Agyan Singh (respondent No. 2) by deed dated October 13, 1952 for 10 years, no allotment order under S. 7(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Gupta, thereafter, leased the premises by a deed dated October 13, 1952 for a period of 10 years to Ram Agyan Singh, respondent No. 2. But there was numberorder allotting the accommodation to him under S. 7 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 used premises for exhibiting cinematography films.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 also used the premises for exhibiting cinematography films.

facts.text: Disputes arose between parties, Gupta filed suits for recovery of rent and ejectment against respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes having arisen between the parties, Gupta filed suits for recovery of rent as well as for ejectment against respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Appellants purchased premises from Ram Swaroop Gupta by sale deed dated March 26, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants purchased the premises in question from Ram Swaroop Gupta by a sale deed dated March, 26, 1962.

facts.text: Appellants filed application under S.7 read with rule 6 for release of accommodation, allowed by Additional District Magistrate on December 3, 1965 on basis of illegal occupation by respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter they filed an application under s. 7 of the Act read with rule 6 made under the Act for release of the accommodation in their favour. On December 3, 1965, the Additional District Magis- trate allowed the application and permitted the appellants to take possession of the premises. That was on the basis that the premises were in illegal occupation of respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Representation by respondent No. 2 against release order rejected by State Government on January 10, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The representation against this order filed by respondent No. 2 to the State Government was rejected on January 10, 1966 on the ground that there was numberprovision for any interference by Government with the order.

facts.text: Appellants filed application for eviction of respondent No. 2 under S.7-A on December 4, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: On December 4, 1965, the appellants filed an application for eviction of respondent No. 2 under s. 7-A of the Act.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate directed issue of notice under clause 2 of S.7-A on June 18, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On June 18, 1966, the Additional  District Magistrate directed issue of numberice under clause  2  of s. 7-A, why respondent No. 2 should number be evicted.

facts.text: Additional District Magistrate passed eviction order against respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Additional District Magistrate passed the order for eviction.

facts.text: Additional Commissioner confirmed eviction order in revision.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 went up in revision against the order to the Additional Commissioner. He companyfirmed the cider of the Additional District Magistrate.

facts.text: State Government allowed revision under S.7-F on October 20, 1967, holding respondent No. 2 not liable to eviction.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2, thereafter, filed an application for revision under s. 7-F of the Act before the State Government against the order. The State Government allowed that application on October 20, 1967 holding that respondent No. 2 was number liable to be evicted from the premises.

facts.text: Learned Single Judge of High Court quashed State Government order.

anchor.surface_text: A learned Single Judge of the Court quashed the order.

facts.text: Division Bench reversed Single Judge order, against which appeal filed with certificate under Art 133(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: Res- pondent No. 2 filed an appeal against the order. The division Bench reversed the order of the learned Single Judge. It is against this order that this appeal has been filed on the basis of a certificate granted under Article 133 1  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 running cinema under licence from 1952, District Magistrate satisfied lawful occupation.

anchor.surface_text: That in effect said that the respondent was running a cinema under a licence in the premises from 1952, that the District Magistrate, when he granted the licence, was satisfied that respondent No. 2 was in lawful occupation

facts.text: In CA 583/1971, appellants filed suit for possession claiming tenancy expired, without permission under S.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, by certificate, we are companycerned with the question whether the suit filed by the appellants for recovery of Possession of the premises which is the subject matter of Civil Appeal NO. 2370 of 1969, on the basis that the tenancy created by Ram Swaroop Gupta,

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit for appellants despite S.3, holding clause 20 of lease deed bars respondent from claiming S.3 benefit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that although the respondent was a tenant against whom the suit cannot be filed without the previous permission as visualised by s. 3 of the Act, yet he cannot claim the benefit of s. 3 on account of clause 20 of the lease deed and decreed the suit.

facts.text: High Court reversed trial court decree, held suit not maintainable under S.3.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the respondent, the High Court reversed the decree, holding that the suit was number maintainable in view of s. 3, and dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Lease deed executed after commencement of Act, no allotment under S.7(2).

anchor.surface_text: The lease deed in question was executed after the companymencement of the Act and the respondent did number obtain an allotment under S. 7 2  of the Act in his favour from the District Magistrate.

facts.text: Respondent paid rent to Gupta and then to appellants after sale.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been paying the rent to Ram Swaroop Gupta and to the appellants after the sale by him to the appellants.

facts.text: Clause 20 of lease deed states parties agree not to claim benefit of Rent Control Act and provisions inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 20 of the deed provides That this agreement of lease has been made between the parties with the knowledge of the existing Rent Control and Eviction Act. The parties do hereby agree and declare that numberparty will ever claim the benefit of the said Acts and that the provisions of the said Acts have been agreed by mutual companysent to be inapplicable to this deed.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal in CA 2370/1969, upheld State Government order.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.

issues.text: whether the learned Single Judge was justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench was of the view that the learned Single Judge was number justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government udder s. 7-F of the Act inasmuch as the order of the State Government did number suffer from any infirmity either on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

issues.text: whether the order of the State Government suffered from any infirmity either on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench was of the view that the learned Single Judge was number justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government udder s. 7-F of the Act inasmuch as the order of the State Government did number suffer from any infirmity either on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

issues.text: whether the circumstances taken into account by the State Government are irrelevant for the exercise of the discretion under the proviso to s. 7-A

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the State Government has taken into account two reasons for exercising its discretion under the proviso in favour of respondent No. 2  1  that respondent No. 2 was in possession from 1953 onwards and was companyducting a cinema in the premises after obtaining a licence from the District Magistrate under the P. Cinema Regulation Act  2  that the District Magistrate when granting the licence to companyduct the cinema must have been satisfied that the respondent was in lawful occupation of the premises. [...] We cannot say that the circumstances taken into account are irrelevant for the exercise of the discretion.

issues.text: whether the State Government, in exercise of revisional jurisdiction under s. 7-F, should not have nullified the effect of the order of release by exercising discretion under proviso to s. 7-A

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte, appearing for the appellants, said that when the Additional District Magistrate passed the order for release on the basis that the appellants require the premises bona fide for their personal occupation, the State Government, in the exercise of its revisional jurisdiction under s. 7-F against the order of eviction under s. 7-A ,should number have nullified the effect of the order of release by exercising its discretion under the proviso to s. 7-A against the appellants.

issues.text: whether the suit filed by the appellants for recovery of possession was maintainable in law without permission under s. 3

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, by certificate, we are companycerned with the question whether the suit filed by the appellants for recovery of Possession of the premises which is the subject matter of Civil Appeal NO. 2370 of 1969, on the basis that the tenancy created by Ram Swaroop Gupta, the predecessor-in-interest of the appellants, in favour of Ram Agyan Singh, the respondent, had expired and, therefore, the appellants were entitled to recover possession of the same, was maintainable in law in view of the fact that it was instituted without obtaining the permission of the District Magistrate under s. 3 1  of the U. P.  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in holding that s. 3 was applicable and, therefore, the suit was not maintainable

anchor.surface_text: The two questions which arise in this appeal are  1  whether the High Court was right in holding that s. 3 was applicable and, therefore, the suit was number maintainable and  2  whether clause 20 of the lease deed was a bar to the respondent from claiming that the provisions of s. 3 were applicable.

issues.text: whether clause 20 of the lease deed was a bar to the respondent from claiming that the provisions of s. 3 were applicable

anchor.surface_text: The two questions which arise in this appeal are  1  whether the High Court was right in holding that s. 3 was applicable and, therefore, the suit was number maintainable and  2  whether clause 20 of the lease deed was a bar to the respondent from claiming that the provisions of s. 3 were applicable.

issues.text: whether the respondent was a tenant under s. 3 despite no allotment order under s. 7(2)

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been paying the rent to Ram Swaroop Gupta and to the appellants after the sale by him to the appellants. Tenant is defined under s. 2 g  of the Act as follows 2 g  Tenant means the person by whom rent is, or but for a companytract express or implied, would be payable for any accommodation. [...] Having regard to the definition clause and the scheme of the Act, we are of opinion that the respondent is a tenant under s. 3 even though EC is occupying the accommodation without an allotment order.

issues.text: whether clause 20 of the lease deed is illegal

anchor.surface_text: The question for companysideration is whether this clause is illegal. Clause 20 companytains two provisions. The first provision is that the parties will never claim the benefit of the Act. The second provision is that the provisions of the Act will be inapplicable to the lease deed.

issues.text: whether s. 3 was enacted only for the benefit of tenants or whether there is a public policy underlying it which precludes a tenant from waiving its benefit

anchor.surface_text: So, the question is, whether s. 3 was enacted only for the benefit of tenants or whether there is a public policy underlying It which precludes a tenant from waiving its benefit.

arguments.claim: State Government should not have nullified the effect of the s.7 release order by exercising discretion under proviso to s.7-A in revision under s.7-F against appellants

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte, appearing for the appellants, said that when the Additional District Magistrate passed the order for release on the basis that the appellants require the premises bona fide for their personal occupation, the State Government, in the exercise of its revisional jurisdiction under s. 7-F against the order of eviction under s. 7-A ,should number have nullified the effect of the order of release by exercising its discretion under the proviso to s. 7-A against the appellants. He also said that the State Government did number even refer to the order for release which would show that it made numberassessment of the hardship to the landlords.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: inference that the State Government was number aware of the order for release on the ground that the appellants required the promises for their perso

arguments.court_reasoning: Separate proceedings; release under s.7 concerns bona fide need, eviction under s.7-A allows respondent to argue inexpediency; no preclusion or necessary inference of unawareness

arguments.claim: Respondent No. 2 entitled to benefit of proviso to s.7-A(1) due to long possession since 1952-53, cinema operation under DM license implying lawful occupation

anchor.surface_text: That in effect said that the respondent was running a cinema under a licence in the premises from 1952, that the District Magistrate, when he granted the licence, was satisfied that respondent No. 2 was in lawful occupation and that, in these circumstances, he was entitled to the benefit of the proviso to s. 7-A 1  of the Act and was number liable to be evicted from the premises.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: circumstances that companyld be taken into companysideration to decide whether it is expedient or inexpedient to order an eviction under the section a

arguments.court_reasoning: Circumstances relevant and not irrelevant for wide discretion under proviso

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.7-A(1) confers wide discretion on District Magistrate/State Government; no exhaustive list of circumstances; factors like long possession relevant

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to sub-section  1  of s. 7-A is companyched in wide language. The dictionary meaning of the word inexpedient is Not expedient disadvantageous in the circumstances unadvisable, impolitic. The circumstances that companyld be taken into companysideration to decide whether it is expedient or inexpedient to order an eviction under the section are number mentioned in the proviso. A great deal of discretion must,therefore, be vested in the District Magistrate and in the State Government when disposing a revision from an order passed by the District Magistrate as several factors would enter the making of the verdict whether it is inexpedient to pass an order of ,eviction under the section.

arguments.claim: Respondent not a tenant under s.3 because no allotment order under s.7(2); lease executed post-Act commencement in violation thereof

It was, therefore, companytended on behalf of the appellants that the respondent was number a tenant within the meaning of that term in s. 3 as the lease was created in violation of the provision of s. 7 2 .

arguments.claim: Respondent qualifies as tenant under s.2(g) and s.3 despite lacking s.7(2) allotment order due to rent payment, estoppel, and Act scheme

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been paying the rent to Ram Swaroop Gupta and to the appellants after the sale by him to the appellants. Tenant is defined under s. 2 g  of the Act as follows 2 g  Tenant means the person by whom rent is, or but for a companytract express or implied, would be payable for any accommodation. [...] Having regard to the definition clause and the scheme of the Act, we are of opinion that the respondent is a tenant under s. 3 even though EC is occupying the accommodation without an allotment order,.

arguments.claim: Clause 20 illegal and void as its object defeats s.3 provisions; unlawful per s.23 Indian Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, an agreement is void if it defeats any provision of law S. 23. The companysideration or object of an agreement is lawful, unless-- it is forbidden by law or is of such a nature, that, if permitted, it would defeat the provisions of any law, or is fraudulent or involves or implies injury to the person or property of another or the Court regards it Lis immoral, or opposed to public policy.

arguments.claim: s.3 founded on public policy to protect tenants (weaker section) from eviction without authority scrutiny; precludes waiver by tenant

anchor.surface_text: The object of s. 3 is to give protection to a tenant from eviction from an accommodation. The policy of the Act seems to be that a responsible authority like the District Magistrate should companysider the claim of the landlord and the needs of the tenant before granting permission. There was alarming scarcity of accommodation. The object of legislature in enacting the law was to protect tenants from greedy and grasping landlords, and from their resorting to companyrt for eviction of tenants without reasonable grounds.

arguments.claim: Single Judge unjustified in quashing State Government s.7-F order; no jurisdictional defect or error of law apparent on face of record

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench was of the view that the learned Single Judge was number justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government udder s. 7-F of the Act inasmuch as the order of the State Government did number suffer from any infirmity either on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rder. The division Bench reversed the order of the learned Single Judge. It is against this order that this appeal has been filed on the basis of a ce

arguments.court_reasoning: SC concurs; no such error; relevant considerations applied

arguments.claim: State Government order not vitiated by error of law apparent; considerations (hardship to respondent from long cinema use) relevant

anchor.surface_text: We are number satisfied that the order of the State Government was vitiated by any error of law apparent on the face of the record. As already stated, the companysiderations which weighed with the State Government in rejecting the application, namely, the hardship to respondent No. 2 who was companyducting a cinema in the premises from 1953 cannot be said to be irrelevant.

holdings.text: The order of the State Government under s. 7-F did not suffer from any infirmity of lack of jurisdiction or error of law apparent on the face of the record.

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench was of the view that the learned Single Judge was not justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F of the Act inasmuch as the order of the State Government did not suffer from any infirmity either on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No jurisdictional defect or error apparent identified; Division Bench view affirmed.

holdings.text: Learned Single Judge was not justified in interfering with State Government order under s. 7-F; Division Bench rightly reversed it.

anchor.surface_text: We are not satisfied that the order of the State Government was vitiated by any error of law apparent on the face of the record. As already stated, the considerations which weighed with the State Government in rejecting the application, namely, the hardship to respondent No. 2 who was conducting a cinema in the premises from 1953 cannot be said to be irrelevant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmed no error apparent; relevant considerations applied by State Government.

holdings.text: Circumstances of long possession since 1953 and cinema license implying lawful occupation are relevant for exercising discretion under proviso to s. 7-A(1).

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the State Government has taken into account two reasons for exercising its discretion under the proviso in favour of respondent No. 2 1 that respondent No. 2 was in possession from 1953 onwards and was conducting a cinema in the premises after obtaining a licence from the District Magistrate under the P. Cinema Regulation Act 2 that the District Magistrate when granting the licence to conduct the cinema must have been satisfied that the respondent was in lawful occupation of the premises. [...] We cannot say that the circumstances taken into account are irrelevant for the exercise of the discretion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso in wide language allows broad factors; these not irrelevant.

holdings.text: Prior release order under s. 7 does not preclude exercise of discretion under proviso to s. 7-A in eviction proceedings; separate stages with different considerations.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte, appearing for the appellants, said that when the Additional District Magistrate passed the order for release on the basis that the appellants require the premises bona fide for their personal occupation, the State Government, in the exercise of its revisional jurisdiction under s. 7-F against the order of eviction under s. 7-A ,should not have nullified the effect of the order of release by exercising its discretion under the proviso to s. 7-A against the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Release concerns bona fide need only; s.7-A stage allows respondent to urge inexpediency factors; no necessary unawareness inferred.

holdings.text: Respondent is a tenant under s. 3 despite absence of allotment order under s. 7(2).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had been paying the rent to Ram Swaroop Gupta and to the appellants after the sale by him to the appellants. Tenant is defined under s. 2 g of the Act as follows 2 g Tenant means the person by whom rent is, or but for a contract express or implied, would be payable for any accommodation. [...] Having regard to the definition clause and the scheme of the Act, we are of opinion that the respondent is a tenant under s. 3 even though he is occupying the accommodation without an allotment order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(g) definition applies via rent payment; lease valid inter partes per precedent; estoppel; Act scheme protects such tenants.

holdings.text: Suit for eviction not maintainable without permission of District Magistrate under s. 3(1); High Court right in so holding.

anchor.surface_text: The two questions which arise in this appeal are 1 whether the High Court was right in holding that s. 3 was applicable and, therefore, the suit was not maintainable and 2 whether clause 20 of the lease deed was a bar to the respondent from claiming that the provisions of s. 3 were applicable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent tenant entitled to s.3 protection; no permission obtained.

holdings.text: Clause 20 of lease deed is illegal and void as it defeats provisions of s. 3.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, an agreement is void if it defeats any provision of law S. 23. The consideration or object of an agreement is lawful, unless-- it is forbidden by law or is of such a nature,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement void under s.23 Contract Act if defeats law provisions like imperative s.3.

holdings.text: Clause 20 does not bar respondent from claiming s. 3 applicability.

anchor.surface_text: The two questions which arise in this appeal are 1 whether the High Court was right in holding that s. 3 was applicable and, therefore, the suit was not maintainable and 2 whether clause 20 of the lease deed was a bar to the respondent from claiming that the provisions of s. 3 were applicable.

holdings.text: s. 3 enacted on public policy protecting weaker tenant class from eviction harassment; tenant cannot waive its benefit.

anchor.surface_text: The object of s. 3 is to give protection to a tenant from eviction from an accommodation. The policy of the Act seems to be that a responsible authority like the District Magistrate should consider the claim of the landlord and the needs of the tenant before granting permission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prohibitive language; protects class interests amid scarcity; distinguishes personal benefits; public policy variable with community needs.

holdings.text: Proviso to s. 7-A(1) vests wide discretion in District Magistrate/State Government; no exhaustive circumstances listed.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to sub-section 1 of s. 7-A is couched in wide language. The dictionary meaning of the word inexpedient is Not expedient disadvantageous in the circumstances unadvisable, impolitic. The circumstances that could be taken into consideration to decide whether it is expedient or inexpedient to order an eviction under the section are not mentioned in the proviso.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'inexpedient'; multiple factors enter decision.

anchor.surface_text: In Udho Dass v. Prem Prakash 1  a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court took the view that a lease made in violation of the provisions of s. 7 2  would be valid between the parties and would create the relationship of landlord and tenant between them although it might number bind the authorities companycerned.

precedents.cited_proposition: a lease made in violation of the provisions of s. 7(2) would be valid between the parties and would create the relationship of landlord and tenant between them although it might not bind the authorities concerned

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gupte, appearing for the appellants, referred to the decision of this Court in Lachoo Mal v. Radhey Shyam 1  and said that  1  1971 3 S.C.R.693. M185 Sup. CI/75 it was open Lo the respondent to waive the benefit of the provision of s. 3 as it was enacted for the benefit of tenants and that numberquestion of public policy is involved.

precedents.cited_proposition: it was open to a landlord to waive the benefit of a provision enacted for the benefit of landlords under the Rent Control Act if no question of public policy involved

anchor.surface_text: see Eserton v. Brownlow, 4 H.L.C. p. 105.  3  1916 1 A.C. 428.  4  see W.S.M. Knight, Public Policy in English Law, 38, Law Quarterly Rev., 207, at pp. 217-218.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between public policy and the policy of the law

anchor.surface_text: see Hollinishead v. Hazleton 3 . Yet it is clearly so used without intent to repudiate or disregard the distinction so clearly drawn in Egerton v. Brownlow. It seems clear that the companyception of public policy is number only number quite distinct from that of the policy of law but has in fact always been so except in some exceptional instances of companyfusion which have had numberSubstantial effect on the general companyrse of authority 4 .

precedents.cited_proposition: public policy used synonymously with policy of the law

precedents.citation: Gherulal Parakh v. Mahadeodas Maiya ors. 1959 Supp. 2, SCR. 406,440

anchor.surface_text: See Gherulal Parakh v. Mahadeodas Maiya ors. 1959 Supp. 2, SCR. 406,440. See Dennis Lloyd, Public Policy  1953 , pp. 112-113.  3  see Percy H. Winfield, Public Policy in English Common Law, 42 Harward Law Rev. 76 and also, Dennis Lloyd, Public- Policy  1953 , pp. 124-125.

precedents.cited_proposition: courts cannot create new heads of public policy

anchor.surface_text: The division Bench was of the view that the learned Single Judge was not justified in interfering with the order passed by the State Government under s. 7-F of the Act inasmuch as the order of the State Government did not suffer from any infirmity either on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to pass the order or for the reason that there was an error of law apparent on the face of the record.
We dismiss the appeal but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.
We dismiss the appeal but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that Single Judge not justified in interfering addresses issue i1 on justification for interference.

anchor.surface_text: We are not satisfied that the order of the State Government was vitiated by any error of law apparent on the face of the record. As already stated, the considerations which weighed with the State Government in rejecting the application, namely, the hardship to respondent No. 2 who was conducting a cinema in the premises from 1953 cannot be said to be irrelevant.
We dismiss the appeal but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.

In this case, the State Government has taken into account two reasons for exercising its discretion under the proviso in favour of respondent No. 2 1 that respondent No. 2 was in possession from 1953 onwards and was conducting a cinema in the premises after obtaining a licence from the District Magistrate under the P. Cinema Regulation Act 2 that the District Magistrate when granting the licence to conduct the cinema must have been satisfied that the respondent was in lawful occupation of the premises. [...] We cannot say that the circumstances taken into account are irrelevant for the exercise of the discretion.
We dismiss the appeal but, in the circumstances, make numberorder as to companyts.
